description: PROPOSED FORMATION OF VEHICULAR ACCESS THROUGH THE INSTALLATION OF A VEHICULAR CROSSOVER.
decision_conditions:
Condition : 1 - The development to which this permission relates shall be commenced not later than the expiration of 3 years from the date of this permission.

Condition : 2 - The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the following approved plans: un-numbered plan illustrating crossover and elevational view dated December 2011 and site location plan received 19/01/12.
Condition : 3 - Prior to the use of the vehicular access and crossover, new boundary gates and fences to provide pedestrian visibility splays as shown on the apporved plans shall be provided and permanently retained.  
          
Reason: In the interests of the safety of pedestrians and vehicles and to comply with policies CS.18:- Active Transport and CS.20:- Parking, Servicing and Delivery of the Merton LDF Core Planning Strategy (2011).

Condition : 4 - REASON FOR APPROVAL.
The proposed installation of a vehicle crossover, suitably conditioned, will not detract from the general conditions of  highway and pedestrian safety and accords with the Council's Adopted Unitary Development Plan, Core Strategy and London Plan Policies. The policies listed below were relevant to the determination of this proposal.
Merton UDP (2003) BE.18: Gardens RN.3 : Vehicular Access
Merton LDF Core Planning Strategy (2011) CS18: Active Transport
CS20: Parking Service & Delivery.


Condition : 5 - INFORMATIVE
It is Council policy for the Council's contractor to construct new vehicular accesses. The applicant should contact the Council's Highways Team on 020 8545 3829 prior to any work starting to arrange for this work to be done. If the applicant wishes to undertake this work the Council will require a deposit and the applicant will need to cover all the Council's costs (including supervision of the works). If the works are of a significant nature, a Section 278 Agreement (Highways Act 1980) will be required and the works must be carried out to the Council's specification.
